text: Fireworks Safety
label: H3

text: Since 1994, fireworks-related injuries have decreased by about one-third.  In
label: BODY

text: 1998, the estimated number of people treated in U.S. hospital emergency rooms
label: BODY

text: for these injuries was 8,500, according to a recent study by staff at the U.S.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC).1 This is in contrast to an
label: BODY

text: estimated 12,500 fireworks-related injuries in 1994.
label: BODY

text: Special Study
label: BODY

text: Each year, in addition to its year-round injury data collection, CPSC staff con-
label: BODY

text: ducts a special study of fireworks injuries that occur around the Fourth of July
label: BODY

text: holiday.
label: BODY

text: About 60% to 75% of fireworks-related injuries occur during this period.
label: BODY

text: The special fireworks study focuses more closely on the kinds of injuries
label: BODY

text: associated with fireworks and the types of fireworks involved.
label: BODY

text: For the 1998 study, CPSC staff examined fireworks-related injuries treated in
label: BODY

text: NEISS hospital emergency rooms between June 23 and July 23, 1998.2 Victims
label: BODY

text: were asked to identify the fireworks type from illustrations shown to them at the
label: BODY

text: emergency room.
label: BODY

text: Injury Data
label: BODY

text: According to the data collected in the special study, children suffered a signifi-
label: BODY

text: cant number of fireworks-related injuries.  In 1998, about 40% of the fireworks-
label: BODY

text: related injuries in the special study occurred to children under age 15.  This is
label: BODY

text: similar to the data in CPSC’s 1997 special study, where children sustained about
label: BODY

text: 38% of these injuries.
label: BODY

text: In 1998, according to the special study, those 15 to 24 years old incurred
label: BODY

text: about 35% of fireworks-related injuries.  The year before, this age group suffered
label: BODY

text: about 26% of these injuries.
label: BODY

text: Males incurred a significantly higher percentage of fireworks-related injuries
label: BODY

text: than females.  In 1998, males suffered about 75% of the injuries.  This was the
label: BODY

text: same as reported in 1997.
label: BODY

text: According to the 1998 special study, the highest percentage of fireworks-relat-
label: BODY

text: ed injuries occurred to people’s hands, followed by eye injuries and head and
label: BODY

text: face injuries.  In 1998, hand injuries accounted for 35% of the total fireworks-re-
label: BODY

text: lated injuries; eye injuries for 20%; and head and face injuries for 20%.  In 1997,
label: BODY

text: hand injuries comprised 35% of the fireworks-related injuries; head injuries for
label: BODY

text: 22%; and eye injuries for 18%.
label: BODY

text: Over half of the injuries in 1998 involved burns.  Eye injuries, however, typi-
label: BODY

text: cally involved contusions or lacerations.  This is similar to the pattern of injuries
label: BODY

text: Continued on page 2
label: BODY

label: HH1

label: HH1

text: I N  T H I S  I S S U E
label: HH2

text: Child Care Settings...........3
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Includes
label: BODY

text: recalls from
label: BODY

text: the National
label: BODY

text: Highway Traffic
label: BODY

text: Safety Administration
label: BODY

text: The type of firework involved in injuries in 1998 also
label: BODY

text: was similar to 1997.  Firecrackers were the leading cause
label: BODY

text: of injury, followed by rockets and sparklers.  About 15%
label: BODY

text: of the injuries were related to illegal fireworks.
label: BODY

text: Fireworks Regulations
label: BODY

text: CPSC enforces a number of fireworks regulations.
label: BODY

text: These include fuse burn time limits, a 50-milligram pow-
label: BODY

text: der limit on firecrackers, requirements to prevent
label: BODY

text: tipover and blowout of devices, and requirements for
label: BODY

text: specific cautionary labeling.  Other regulations affect
label: BODY

text: certain reloadable tube aerial shell fireworks and stabili-
label: BODY

text: ty requirements for multiple tube devices.
label: BODY

text: Millennium Celebration
label: BODY

text: To highlight the importance of fireworks safety, CPSC
label: BODY

text: has spearheaded a national public awareness campaign
label: BODY

text: to promote fireworks safety during the millennium cele-
label: BODY

text: brations and is an official partner of the White House
label: BODY

text: Millennium Council.  CPSC is working cooperatively
label: BODY

text: with a broad range of national, state, and local organiza-
label: BODY

text: tions to disseminate information about fireworks safety.
label: BODY

text: (See Millennium Fireworks Tips.)  The campaign will run
label: BODY

text: from July 4, 1999 through New Year’s Day 2001.
label: BODY

text: — Michael A. Greene, Ph.D, Directorate for Epidemiology and
label: BODY

text: Health Sciences
label: BODY

text: References:
label: BODY

text: 11998 fireworks-related injuries: a study of fireworks-related in-
label: BODY

text: juries treated in hospital emergency rooms between June 23 and
label: BODY

text: July 23, 1998.  Washington, DC: CPSC, 1999.
label: BODY

text: 2CPSC.  National Electronic Injury Surveillance System (NEISS).
label: BODY

text: NEISS is a statistical sample of hospitals nationwide that have
label: BODY

text: emergency departments.  Each day, NEISS hospitals report to
label: BODY

text: CPSC all emergency room-treated injuries associated with
label: BODY

text: consumer products and related activities.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: Millennium Fireworks Tips
label: BODY

text: Fireworks can be dangerous, causing serious burn
label: BODY

text: and eye injuries. That’s why CPSC and its national
label: BODY

text: and state partners strongly recommend that you
label: BODY

text: leave fireworks to the professionals.
label: BODY

text: But if fireworks are legal where you live and you de-
label: BODY

text: cide to set them off on your own, be sure to follow
label: BODY

text: these important safety tips:
label: BODY

text: I Never allow children to play with or ignite fire-
label: BODY

text: works.
label: BODY

text: I Read and follow all warnings and instructions.
label: BODY

text: I Be sure other people are out of range before
label: BODY

text: lighting fireworks.
label: BODY

text: I Only light fireworks on a smooth, flat surface
label: BODY

text: away from the house, dry leaves, and flammable
label: BODY

text: materials.
label: BODY

text: I Never try to relight fireworks that have not fully
label: BODY

text: functioned.
label: BODY

text: I Keep a bucket of water handy in case of a mal-
label: BODY

text: function or fire.
label: BODY

text: For more information about fireworks safety, visit
label: BODY

text: CPSC’s website at: www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/pubs/
label: BODY

text: july4/4thjuly.html.
label: BODY

text: For More Information
label: BODY

text: For a complete copy of the report, 1998 Fireworks-
label: BODY

text: Related Injuries, please contact:
label: BODY

text: Office of the Secretary
label: BODY

text: U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20207
label: BODY

text: or visit CPSC’s website at www.cpsc.gov.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: CPSC staff recently conducted a national study that
label: BODY

text: identified potential safety hazards at child care settings
label: BODY

text: across the country. The staff found at least one of the
label: BODY

text: targeted safety hazards at two-thirds of the 220 licensed
label: BODY

text: child care settings visited.1
label: BODY

text: CPSC staff looked at eight product areas with poten-
label: BODY

text: tial safety hazards. These included: cribs, soft bedding,
label: BODY

text: playground surfacing, playground surfacing mainte-
label: BODY

text: nance, child safety gates, window blind cords, draw-
label: BODY

text: strings in children’s clothing, and recalled children’s
label: BODY

text: products.
label: BODY

text: These potential hazard areas were chosen because
label: BODY

text: they are a source of injury to children in and around
label: BODY

text: their homes and could be equally hazardous in child
label: BODY

text: care settings.
label: BODY

text: Some of the targeted hazards were more obvious
label: BODY

text: ones, like problems with used cribs or playground sur-
label: BODY

text: facing. For example, more babies (about 40 to 50 each
label: BODY

text: year) die in incidents involving cribs than any other
label: BODY

text: piece of nursery equipment. Since 1990, at least nine
label: BODY

text: children have died in crib-related incidents in child care
label: BODY

text: settings.2
label: BODY

text: For young children, playground-related injuries ac-
label: BODY

text: count for more visits to U.S. hospital emergency rooms
label: BODY

text: than any other child care-related injury. For example, in
label: BODY

text: 1997, about 60,000 children under 5 were treated in
label: BODY

text: hospital emergency rooms for all playground-related in-
label: BODY

text: juries. About 8,000 of these injuries occurred in child
label: BODY

text: care/school settings.3
label: BODY

text: Other potential hazards, like soft bedding or window
label: BODY

text: blind cords, were selected because caregivers might not
label: BODY

text: be aware of potential dangers. CPSC recently issued new
label: BODY

text: guidelines on soft bedding in cribs, urging that all soft
label: BODY

text: bedding be removed from cribs when babies are put
label: BODY

text: down to sleep. (See Soft Bedding, page 5.)
label: BODY

text: About one child a month strangles in window cover-
label: BODY

text: ing cords. These deaths have occurred both at home
label: BODY

text: and in child care settings.
label: BODY

text: Background Data
label: BODY

text: CPSC has reports of at least 56 children who have died
label: BODY

text: in child care settings since 1990. At least 28 of these chil-
label: BODY

text: dren died from suffocation and/or asphyxia related to
label: BODY

text: nursery equipment or soft bedding.
label: BODY

text: About 31,000 children, 4 years old and younger, were
label: BODY

text: treated in U.S. hospital emergency rooms for injuries at
label: BODY

text: child care/school settings in 1997. The playground-re-
label: BODY

text: lated injuries (8,000 in 1997) were the largest single
label: BODY

text: cause.
label: BODY

text: There are 21 million children under age 6 in this
label: BODY

text: country; almost 13 million of them are placed in non-
label: BODY

text: parental child care during some portion of the day.
label: BODY

text: About 29% of these children are in center-based care,
label: BODY

text: including child care centers, Head Start programs, and
label: BODY

text: nursery schools. The other 71% of these children are in
label: BODY

text: non-center-based care, including family child care, in-
label: BODY

text: home care, and care by a relative.
label: BODY

text: ECOSA Conference
label: H3

text: For the first time, CPSC will co-sponsor the
label: BODY

text: International Conference on Product Safety Research
label: BODY

text: with the European Consumer Safety Association
label: BODY

text: (ECOSA). This seventh annual international conference
label: BODY

text: will be held on September 30 and October 1, 1999 near
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC in Bethesda, MD.
label: BODY

text: The 1999 conference will focus on such topics as new
label: BODY

text: consumer product safety issues; benefits of protective
label: BODY

text: safety equipment; fire hazards and effective intervention
label: BODY

text: strategies; children’s hazards; and costs and benefits of
label: BODY

text: product safety improvements.
label: BODY

text: The conference is especially designed for those from
label: BODY

text: consumer safety agencies and injury control organiza-
label: BODY

text: tions, consumer groups, national and international stan-
label: BODY

text: dardization bodies, testing laboratories, consumer prod-
label: BODY

text: uct manufacturers and designers, the research commu-
label: BODY

text: nity, and trade associations.
label: BODY

text: Last year, the ECOSA-sponsored conference was held
label: BODY

text: in Amsterdam. ECOSA is a non-profit organization con-
label: BODY

text: cerned with the safe design of consumer products.
label: BODY

text: For more information about the 1999 conference,
label: BODY

text: visit www.ecosa.org and click on “news.”  Or, contact:
label: BODY

text: ECOSA Secretariat, P.O. 75169, NL-1070 AD
label: BODY

text: Amsterdam, The Netherlands (e-mail: R.Molenaar@con-
label: BODY

text: safe.nl or S.Geldhof@consafe.nl at ECOSA or akirshn-
label: BODY

text: er@cpsc.gov at CPSC).
label: BODY

text: Continued on page 4
label: BODY

text: Safety at Child Care Settings
label: H3

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: There are about 99,000 licensed child care centers in
label: BODY

text: the U.S. In addition, there are about 283,000 regulated
label: BODY

text: or licensed family child care providers. In CPSC’s staff
label: BODY

text: review of state licensing requirements for child care,
label: BODY

text: however, most of the hazards included in this child care
label: BODY

text: study were not addressed.
label: BODY

text: For example, although cribs are covered by both fed-
label: BODY

text: eral regulations and voluntary safety standards, many
label: BODY

text: states did not require child care centers to use cribs that
label: BODY

text: met all of these standards. Although virtually all child
label: BODY

text: care settings use nursery equipment, like high chairs
label: BODY

text: and strollers, none of the states reviewed had require-
label: BODY

text: ments for addressing recalled nursery equipment.
label: BODY

text: Description of Study
label: BODY

text: To conduct the study, CPSC staff visited four different
label: BODY

text: types of child care settings. These included: 23
label: BODY

text: Government Services Administration (GSA)-managed
label: BODY

text: child care centers  (sponsored by Cabinet-level and inde-
label: BODY

text: pendent federal government agencies); 77 non-profit
label: BODY

text: centers; 68 in-home settings; and 52 for-profit centers.
label: BODY

text: These child care settings were spread across the
label: BODY

text: country. These included 73 child care settings in the
label: BODY

text: east, 76 in the west, and 71 in the central part of the
label: BODY

text: country. Within each region, about 10% of the child
label: BODY

text: care settings were GSA-sponsored; 40% were non-profit;
label: BODY

text: 30% were in-home; and 20% were for-profit.
label: BODY

text: Where possible, participating child care settings were
label: BODY

text: selected randomly from regional or national lists of li-
label: BODY

text: censed child care providers. When such lists were not
label: BODY

text: available, selections were made from a variety of other
label: BODY

text: sources, including Internet sites and local yellow pages.
label: BODY

text: CPSC staff used a prepared checklist to observe con-
label: BODY

text: ditions related to the eight product areas. Information
label: BODY

text: from the checklists was entered into a database for fur-
label: BODY

text: ther analysis.
label: BODY

text: Results of the Study
label: BODY

text: Many child care settings provide safe environments for
label: BODY

text: young children. Yet CPSC staff found the following re-
label: BODY

text: sults at the child care settings included in this study.
label: BODY

text: I 8% of the child care settings had cribs that did not
label: BODY

text: meet current safety standards.
label: BODY

text: I 19% of the child care settings had cribs that contained
label: BODY

text: soft bedding.
label: BODY

text: I 24% of the child care settings did not have safe play-
label: BODY

text: ground surfacing.
label: BODY

text: I 27% of the child care settings did not keep the play-
label: BODY

text: ground surfacing well-maintained.
label: BODY

text: I 13% of the child care settings did not use child safety
label: BODY

text: gates where necessary.
label: BODY

text: I 26% of the child care settings had loops on the win-
label: BODY

text: dow blind cords.
label: BODY

text: I 38% of the child care settings had children wearing
label: BODY

text: clothing with drawstrings at the neck.
label: BODY

text: I 5% of the child care settings had products that had
label: BODY

text: been recalled by CPSC.
label: BODY

text: Preventing Injuries
label: BODY

text: CPSC staff found that most (two-thirds) of the child care
label: BODY

text: settings in the study had at least one safety hazard,
label: BODY

text: putting children in these settings at risk of possible in-
label: BODY

text: jury or death. CPSC staff’s review of state licensing re-
label: BODY

text: quirements indicated that most of the hazards included
label: BODY

text: in the study were not adequately addressed in these re-
label: BODY

text: quirements.
label: BODY

text: To help prevent deaths and injuries at child care set-
label: BODY

text: tings, CPSC released a Child Care Safety Checklist for par-
label: BODY

text: ents and child care providers. (See page 6.)
label: BODY

text: This checklist is intended to help adults easily identi-
label: BODY

text: fy potential safety hazards both at child care settings and
label: BODY

text: at home. CPSC staff is sending the checklist to national
label: BODY

text: child care groups, state licensing authorities, and other
label: BODY

text: child care providers and organizations. Many of these
label: BODY

text: groups are reprinting and distributing the checklist.
label: BODY

text: — Carol Cave, Directorate for Field Operations, and Debra
label: BODY

text: Sweet, Directorate for Epidemiology and Health Sciences
label: BODY

text: Child Care Safety: First Lady Speaks Out
label: BODY

text: First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton joined CPSC
label: BODY

text: Chairman Ann Brown to kick off a national cam-
label: BODY

text: paign to alert parents and caregivers to safety haz-
label: BODY

text: ards in child care settings. On April 12, 1999, at a
label: BODY

text: child care center in downtown Washington, DC, the
label: BODY

text: First Lady and Chairman Brown announced the re-
label: BODY

text: sults of the CPSC staff’s study and the availability of
label: BODY

text: the CPSC child care safety checklist.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: Soft Bedding
label: H3

text: Dr. N.J. Scheers, Project Manager of the Infant
label: BODY

text: Suffocation Project, discusses the new recommenda-
label: BODY

text: tions for soft bedding in cribs and the association of
label: BODY

text: soft bedding with sudden infant death syndrome
label: BODY

text: (SIDS).
label: BODY

text: What’s new about how babies should be placed to sleep?
label: BODY

text: We’re recommending that when you put a baby down
label: BODY

text: to sleep, be sure all soft bedding — like comforters,
label: BODY

text: quilts, pillows, sheepskins, and pillow-like toys — is re-
label: BODY

text: moved from the crib.
label: BODY

text: How is this new recommendation on soft bedding different
label: BODY

text: from the old one?
label: BODY

text: For years, we recommended that soft bedding not be
label: BODY

text: placed underneath babies. That’s because babies, in-
label: BODY

text: cluding those correctly placed to sleep on their backs,
label: BODY

text: can roll over, and the bedding can become molded
label: BODY

text: around the infant’s face, nose, and mouth. Based on
label: BODY

text: further research, we’re now recommending, in addi-
label: BODY

text: tion, that no comforters or heavy quilts be used to
label: BODY

text: cover the baby.
label: BODY

text: One critical recommendation that remains un-
label: BODY

text: changed is that babies should be put down to sleep
label: BODY

text: on their backs, on a firm, tight-fitting mattress, in a
label: BODY

text: crib that meets all current safety standards.
label: BODY

text: What research findings led to this new recommendation on
label: BODY

text: soft bedding?
label: BODY

text: Research found that babies are at increased risk for
label: BODY

text: SIDS if they get their heads covered by soft bedding
label: BODY

text: while sleeping. The research showed that this can oc-
label: BODY

text: cur even when they’re sleeping on their backs or
label: BODY

text: sides.
label: BODY

text: How is soft bedding related to SIDS?
label: BODY

text: Since the Back-to-Sleep campaign, deaths from SIDS
label: BODY

text: have dropped dramatically, by over 2,000 a year.
label: BODY

text: However, about 3,000 babies still die of SIDS each
label: BODY

text: year, and past studies suggest that some may have suf-
label: BODY

text: focated when placed to sleep on top of soft bedding.
label: BODY

text: If comforters or quilts are not recommended to keep babies
label: BODY

text: warm, what can be used?
label: BODY

text: Consider putting the baby in a sleeper. If you must
label: BODY

text: use a blanket, use a thin
label: BODY

text: one. Place the baby with
label: BODY

text: his or her feet at the foot
label: BODY

text: of the crib. Then tuck
label: BODY

text: the blanket around the
label: BODY

text: crib mattress, extending
label: BODY

text: the blanket only as far as
label: BODY

text: the baby’s chest. (See
label: BODY

text: picture at left.)
label: BODY

text: For what ages do these rec-
label: BODY

text: ommendations apply?
label: BODY

text: We recommend that all
label: BODY

text: soft bedding be removed
label: BODY

text: from cribs of children
label: BODY

text: under 12 months.
label: BODY

text: Is it safe to put babies down to sleep in places other than
label: BODY

text: cribs?
label: BODY

text: We recommend that babies not be placed to sleep on
label: BODY

text: soft surfaces like waterbeds, sofas, soft mattresses, and
label: BODY

text: pillows. There’s always the possibility of suffocation if
label: BODY

text: the soft surface molds around the baby’s face.
label: BODY

text: Do pediatricians agree with these new recommendations
label: BODY

text: on soft bedding?
label: BODY

text: The American Academy of Pediatrics, along with the
label: BODY

text: National Institute of Child Health and Human
label: BODY

text: Development, joined CPSC in issuing a recent safety
label: BODY

text: alert that warned against placing babies to sleep in an
label: BODY

text: environment with soft bedding.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: Here are some safety tips for parents and child care
label: BODY

text: providers to use at child care settings. For a complete
label: BODY

text: version of the checklist (in English or Spanish), visit
label: BODY

text: CPSC’s website at www.cpsc.gov or send a postcard to:
label: BODY

text: Child Care Safety Checklist
label: BODY

text: CPSC
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20207
label: BODY

text: l CRIBS
label: BODY

text: Make sure cribs meet current national safety stan-
label: BODY

text: dards and are in good condition. Look for a certifica-
label: BODY

text: tion safety seal. Older cribs may not meet current
label: BODY

text: standards. Crib slats should be no more than 2 3/8”
label: BODY

text: apart, and mattresses should fit snugly.
label: BODY

text: l SOFT BEDDING
label: BODY

text: Be sure that no pillows, soft bedding, or comforters
label: BODY

text: are used when you put babies to sleep. Babies should
label: BODY

text: be put to sleep on their backs in a crib with a firm,
label: BODY

text: flat mattress.
label: BODY

text: l PLAYGROUND SURFACING
label: BODY

text: Look for safe surfacing on outdoor playgrounds — at
label: BODY

text: least 12 inches of wood chips, mulch, sand or pea
label: BODY

text: gravel, or mats made of safety-tested rubber or rub-
label: BODY

text: ber-like materials.
label: BODY

text: References:
label: BODY

text: 1CPSC staff study of safety hazards in child care settings.
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC: CPSC, April 1999.
label: BODY

text: 2CPSC. Medical Examiners and Coroners Alert Project (MECAP).
label: BODY

text: MECAP is a national voluntary reporting system for 2,500 coro-
label: BODY

text: ners and medical examiners nationwide to report consumer prod-
label: BODY

text: uct-related deaths to CPSC. CPSC also purchases death
label: BODY

text: certificates from 50 states and the District of Columbia for deaths
label: BODY

text: related to consumer products.
label: BODY

text: 3CPSC. National Electronic Injury Surveillance System (NEISS).
label: BODY

text: l PLAYGROUND MAINTENANCE
label: BODY

text: Check playground surfacing and equipment regularly
label: BODY

text: to make sure they are maintained in good condition.
label: BODY

text: l SAFETY GATES
label: BODY

text: Be sure that safety gates are used to keep children
label: BODY

text: away from potentially dangerous areas, especially
label: BODY

text: stairs.
label: BODY

text: l WINDOW BLIND AND CURTAIN CORDS
label: BODY

text: Be sure mini-blinds and venetian blinds do not have
label: BODY

text: looped cords. Check that vertical blinds, continuous
label: BODY

text: looped blinds, and drapery cords have tension or tie-
label: BODY

text: down devices to hold the cords tight.
label: BODY

text: l CLOTHING DRAWSTRINGS
label: BODY

text: Be sure there are no drawstrings around the hood
label: BODY

text: and neck of children’s outerwear clothing. Other
label: BODY

text: types of clothing fasteners, like snaps, zippers, or
label: BODY

text: hook and loop fasteners (such as Velcro), should be
label: BODY

text: used.
label: BODY

text: l RECALLED PRODUCTS
label: BODY

text: Check that no recalled products are being used and
label: BODY

text: that a current list of recalled children’s products is
label: BODY

text: readily visible.
label: BODY

text: For More Information
label: H4

text: For a copy of the complete CPSC Staff Study of
label: BODY

text: Safety Hazards in Child Care Settings, please visit
label: BODY

text: CPSC’s website at www.cpsc.gov or contact: Office
label: BODY

text: of the Secretary, U.S. Consumer Product Safety
label: BODY

text: Commission, Washington, DC 20207, 301-504-
label: BODY

text: To get all CPSC product recall information
label: BODY

text: faxed directly to you (or to a child care facility),
label: BODY

text: send a fax with your name and fax number to 301-
label: BODY

text: 504-0399. To receive recall information by e-mail,
label: BODY

text: send an e-mail message to listproc@cpsc.gov and,
label: BODY

text: in the message area, enter: Join CPSCINFO-L.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999

text: Consumer Product Incident Report
label: H3

text: Please contact us about any injury or death involving consumer products. Call us toll free at: 1-800-638-8095.
label: BODY

text: Visit our website at www.cpsc.gov. Or, fill out the form below. Send it to: U.S. Consumer Product Safety
label: BODY

text: Commission/EHDS, Washington, DC 20207 or fax it to: 1-800-809-0924. We may contact you for further
label: BODY

text: details. Please provide as much information as possible. Thank you.
label: BODY

text: CPSC FORM 175A (6/96)       OMB CLEARANCE NO. 3041-0029
label: BODY

text: *A male, 3, was playing in his yard
label: BODY

text: on playground climbing equipment
label: BODY

text: when his scarf caught on the climb-
label: BODY

text: ing apparatus. His mother found
label: BODY

text: him hanging from the playground
label: BODY

text: equipment. The cause of death was
label: BODY

text: asphyxia.
label: BODY

text: (Delores Jones-Butler for Carolyn
label: BODY

text: Rivercomb, M.D., Medical Examiner,
label: BODY

text: Philadelphia, PA)
label: BODY

text: A male, 5 months was found
label: BODY

text: wedged between a mattress and the
label: BODY

text: metal grating at the foot of an adult
label: BODY

text: bed. The victim was taken to the hos-
label: BODY

text: pital, where he died. The cause of
label: BODY

text: death was mechanical asphyxia.
label: BODY

text: (D. Jones for John Jofko, M.D.,
label: BODY

text: Medical Examiner and William
label: BODY

text: Massello, III, M.D., Pathologist,
label: BODY

text: Western District, Roanoke, VA)
label: BODY

text: A male, 3 months, was placed face
label: BODY

text: down on a soft adult pillow inside his
label: BODY

text: bassinet to sleep. He was found unre-
label: BODY

text: sponsive. The cause of death was po-
label: BODY

text: sitional asphyxia.
label: BODY

text: (Manfred C. Borges, Jr., M.D.,
label: BODY

text: Associate Medical Examiner, Collier
label: BODY

text: County, Naples, FL)
label: BODY

text: *A male, 7 months, was gagging
label: BODY

text: on a piece of balloon, when his fa-
label: BODY

text: ther found him. The father also
label: BODY

text: found several balloons lying on the
label: BODY

text: floor. The cause of death was asphyx-
label: BODY

text: ia and upper airway obstruction.
label: BODY

text: (Antoinette J. Tibbs for L.
label: BODY

text: Sathyavagiswaran, M.D., Chief
label: BODY

text: Medical Examiner, Los Angeles
label: BODY

text: County, Los Angeles, CA)
label: BODY

text: A female, 7 months, was placed
label: BODY

text: on an adult-size bed to sleep. She was
label: BODY

text: found wedged between the head-
label: BODY

text: board and the mattress of the bed.
label: BODY

text: The cause of death was positional as-
label: BODY

text: phyxia.
label: BODY

text: (Rebecca Bluedorn, RN, for
label: BODY

text: Theodore Soboslay, M.D., Coroner,
label: BODY

text: Trunbull County, Warren, OH)
label: BODY

text: During the months of January, February
label: BODY

text: and March 1999, 1,013 cases were
label: BODY

text: reported to CPSC. Included here are
label: BODY

text: samples of cases to illustrate the type and
label: BODY

text: nature of the reported incidents.
label: BODY

text: ASPHYXIATIONS/
label: BODY

text: SUFFOCATIONS
label: BODY

text: *A male, 3 months, was found
label: BODY

text: trapped between the mattress and
label: BODY

text: the side of his crib by his mother.
label: BODY

text: The child’s father attempted CPR.
label: BODY

text: The cause of death was positional
label: BODY

text: asphyxia.
label: BODY

text: (Drew Toler for Thomas Young,
label: BODY

text: M.D., Pathologist, Jackson County,
label: BODY

text: Kansas City, MO)
label: BODY

text: *A female, 8 months, was swing-
label: BODY

text: ing in an infant swing. She caught
label: BODY

text: her neck on the shoulder harness
label: BODY

text: strap of the swing and died. The
label: BODY

text: cause of death was accidental hang-
label: BODY

text: ing.
label: BODY

text: (Mary Coffman for Jeffrey Barnard,
label: BODY

text: M.D., Medical Examiner, Dallas
label: BODY

text: County, Dallas, TX)
label: BODY

text: A female, 1, was placed in a
label: BODY

text: daybed to sleep. She was later found
label: BODY

text: by her mother with her head be-
label: BODY

text: tween the metal rails of the head-
label: BODY

text: board and her body resting on the
label: BODY

text: metal mattress frame of the bed.
label: BODY

text: The cause of death was asphyxia.
label: BODY

text: (Terry Browne, Deputy Coroner for
label: BODY

text: Cyril H. Wecht, M.D., J.D., Coroner,
label: BODY

text: Allegheny County, Pittsburgh, PA)

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Emergency Physicians
label: BODY

text: Reporting System
label: BODY

text: The MECAP-EPRS Project is
label: BODY

text: designed to collect timely
label: BODY

text: information on deaths and
label: BODY

text: injuries involving consumer
label: BODY

text: products. Please contact us
label: BODY

text: whenever you encounter a
label: BODY

text: death or situation that you
label: BODY

text: believe should be considered
label: BODY

text: during a safety evaluation of
label: BODY

text: a product.
label: BODY

text: To report a case or ask for
label: BODY

text: information about MECAP,
label: BODY

text: please call our toll-free
label: BODY

text: or our toll-free fax number,
label: BODY

text: message via Internet to
label: BODY

text: AMCDONAL@CPSC.GOV.
label: BODY

text: *Indicates cases selected for
label: BODY

text: CPSC follow-up investigations.
label: BODY

text: Cases reported but not
label: BODY

text: selected for follow-up also
label: BODY

text: are important to CPSC. Every
label: BODY

text: MECAP report is included in
label: BODY

text: CPSC’s injury data base and
label: BODY

text: will be used to assess the
label: BODY

text: hazards associated with
label: BODY

text: consumer products.
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: *A female, 24 weeks, was seated
label: BODY

text: in an infant swing. She slid down in
label: BODY

text: the seat and was strangled by the
label: BODY

text: waist strap. The swing’s lap belt,
label: BODY

text: which went between the infant’s legs,
label: BODY

text: was missing. The cause of death was
label: BODY

text: asphyxia.
label: BODY

text: (Butch M. Houston, M.D., Medical
label: BODY

text: Examiner, Milwaukee, WI)
label: BODY

text: POISONINGS
label: BODY

text: A male, 68, used a propane
label: BODY

text: heater to warm an unvented camp-
label: BODY

text: ing trailer during cold weather. He
label: BODY

text: was found dead by his son. The
label: BODY

text: cause of death was carbon monoxide
label: BODY

text: poisoning.
label: BODY

text: (Michael S. Birchmeyer for Mary
label: BODY

text: Jumbelic, M.D., Chief Medical
label: BODY

text: Examiner, Onondaga County,
label: BODY

text: Syracuse, NY)
label: BODY

text: *Two males, 47 and 52, were
label: BODY

text: found dead in their home. The gas
label: BODY

text: furnace had malfunctioned. The
label: BODY

text: cause of death was carbon monoxide
label: BODY

text: poisoning.
label: BODY

text: (Venus Azar, M.D., Medical
label: BODY

text: Examiner, Richmond, VA)
label: BODY

text: DROWNINGS
label: BODY

text: A female, 2, went to an apartment
label: BODY

text: complex playground with her 8-and
label: BODY

text: 10-year-old cousins. The victim disap-
label: BODY

text: peared. She was found floating face
label: BODY

text: up in the apartment complex pool.
label: BODY

text: The victim gained access to the pool
label: BODY

text: through an open gate. The cause of
label: BODY

text: death was drowning.
label: BODY

text: (Parviz Pakdaman, M.D., Medical
label: BODY

text: Examiner, Santa Clara County, San
label: BODY

text: Jose, CA)
label: BODY

text: *A male, 39, was scuba diving. He
label: BODY

text: called to his girl friend that he was
label: BODY

text: having trouble with the regulator on
label: BODY

text: his equipment and then sank below
label: BODY

text: the water’s surface. He was recov-
label: BODY

text: ered, and CPR was attempted. The
label: BODY

text: cause of death was drowning.
label: BODY

text: (Gary G. Bluemink, M.D., Medical
label: BODY

text: Examiner, Norfolk, VA)
label: BODY

text: FIRES
label: BODY

text: A male, 86, died in a house fire
label: BODY

text: caused by a faulty electric heater.
label: BODY

text: The cause of death was burns to
label: BODY

text: 75% total body surface.
label: BODY

text: (Samantha L. Wetzler, M.D.,
label: BODY

text: Medical Examiner, Richmond, VA)
label: BODY

text: A male, 18, died in a house fire.
label: BODY

text: His mother had poured gasoline
label: BODY

text: from one container to another in a
label: BODY

text: utility room. A gas water heater in
label: BODY

text: the room ignited fumes from the
label: BODY

text: gasoline. The cause of death was
label: BODY

text: smoke inhalation.
label: BODY

text: (Susan Haddak for William R. Bell,
label: BODY

text: M.D., Medical Examiner and Gary
label: BODY

text: D. Cumberland, M.D., Chief
label: BODY

text: Medical Examiner, Pensacola, FL)
label: BODY

text: A female, 55, died in a house fire
label: BODY

text: caused by a faulty electrical outlet.
label: BODY

text: The cause of death was smoke in-
label: BODY

text: halation.
label: BODY

text: (Nancy Moore for John Butts, M.D.,
label: BODY

text: Chief Medical Examiner, Chapel
label: BODY

text: Hill, NC)
label: BODY

text: *A male, 88, died in a house
label: BODY

text: fire caused by a faulty heater con-
label: BODY

text: trol on an electric blanket. The
label: BODY

text: cause of death was thermal burns.
label: BODY

text: (Nancy Moore for John Butts,
label: BODY

text: M.D., Chief Medical Examiner,
label: BODY

text: Chapel Hill, NC)

text: ELECTROCUTIONS
label: BODY

text: A male, 31, was installing an ice-
label: BODY

text: maker at a friend’s house. He was
label: BODY

text: holding a water pipe in one hand
label: BODY

text: and using cutters with the other
label: BODY

text: hand. He cut a live 220 volt electri-
label: BODY

text: cal conduit. The cause of death
label: BODY

text: was electrocution.
label: BODY

text: (Nancy Moore for John Butts,
label: BODY

text: M.D., Chief Medical Examiner,
label: BODY

text: Chapel Hill, NC)
label: BODY

text: A female, 82, died while using a
label: BODY

text: hedge trimmer. Her gold metal
label: BODY

text: necklace made contact with a
label: BODY

text: loosely-connected electrical plug
label: BODY

text: in the hedge trimmer. The cause
label: BODY

text: of death was electrocution.
label: BODY

text: (Eroston A. Price, M.D., Medical
label: BODY

text: Examiner, Ft. Lauderdale, FL)
label: BODY

text: MISCELLANEOUS
label: BODY

text: A male, 2, hugged a 64-pound
label: BODY

text: TV while watching his favorite
label: BODY

text: character on a TV show. The TV
label: BODY

text: was on a particleboard stand. The
label: BODY

text: TV fell off the stand onto the
label: BODY

text: child. The cause of death was
label: BODY

text: blunt force trauma of the head.
label: BODY

text: (Terry Browne, Deputy Coroner
label: BODY

text: for Cyril H. Wecht, M.D., J.D.,
label: BODY

text: Allegheny County, Pittsburgh, PA)

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: CPSC Recalls
label: H3

text: The following product recalls were conducted by firms in cooperation with
label: BODY

text: CPSC. For more information about recalls, visit CPSC’s website at
label: BODY

text: www.cpsc.gov.
label: BODY

text: Product: About 78,000 power mowers by Toro Co. The mowers
label: BODY

text: are Lawn-Boy Silver Series, Four Cycle, walk-behind 21-inch mow-
label: BODY

text: 10307 (with serial number ranges 7900001-7999999); 10249
label: BODY

text: number and serial number are printed on a decal on the right
label: BODY

text: rear of the mower. Lawn-Boy dealers and mass merchant retail
label: BODY

text: outlets, including Sears, Lowe’s and Home Depot, sold these
label: BODY

text: mowers from January 1997 through November 1998 for between
label: BODY

text: Problem: Interference with the mower’s mulching fan can cause
label: BODY

text: the mower blade to crack and break off. Broken pieces of the
label: BODY

text: blade can be propelled from under the mower, possibly injuring
label: BODY

text: someone. One consumer was struck on the ankle while mowing,
label: BODY

text: resulting in a bruised tendon.
label: BODY

text: What to do: Stop using the mowers until they are repaired.
label: BODY

text: Contact Lawn-Boy at 1-800-444-8676 between 7:30 a.m. and 4:30
label: BODY

text: p.m. CDT M-F or at www.lawnboy.com to locate the nearest
label: BODY

text: Lawn-Boy service dealer for free repair or for more information.
label: BODY

text: Product: About 274,000 battery-powered children’s riding vehicles
label: BODY

text: by Peg Perego. The vehicles run on 12 volts, powered by two 6-volt
label: BODY

text: batteries and were manufactured before December 1997. The
label: BODY

text: plastic vehicles have the following model names: Corral 270,
label: BODY

text: Diablo, Dragon, Gaucho, Gaucho Grande, Gaucho High Torque,
label: BODY

text: Gaucho Sport, Magica, Magnum, Ranger GT, Thunderbolt,
label: BODY

text: Thundercat, and Tornado. The model name and Peg Perego ap-
label: BODY

text: pear on each vehicle. Peg Perego vehicles are intended for chil-
label: BODY

text: dren from 3 to 8 years old and have speed ranges from 2.5 to 5
label: BODY

text: mph. Toy stores and retail catalogs sold the vehicles nationwide
label: BODY

text: from 1990 through 1997 for about $100 to $550. Vehicles made
label: BODY

text: since 1998 and 6-volt, single battery vehicles are not recalled.
label: BODY

text: Problem: The pedals can stick and electrical components can
label: BODY

text: overheat, presenting fire and injury hazards to children. There
label: BODY

text: have been about 320 reports of electrical components overheat-
label: BODY

text: ing or pedals sticking. Thirty fires have been reported, resulting
label: BODY

text: in one child suffering second-degree burns to his hand and at
label: BODY

text: least $55,000 in property damage. One child suffered a concus-
label: BODY

text: sion and six children were bruised when accelerator pedals stuck
label: BODY

text: and the vehicles hit trees, fences, walls, or parked automobiles.
label: BODY

text: What to do: Remove the vehicles’ batteries right away and don’t
label: BODY

text: let children use them until repairs are made. Contact Peg Perego
label: BODY

text: at 1-888-893-7903 between 8 a.m. and 8 p.m. EST M-F or at
label: BODY

text: www.perego.com/recall1.htm to order a free repair kit that can
label: BODY

text: be installed by consumers or by an authorized Peg Perego service
label: BODY

text: center. Service centers will not have repair kits.
label: BODY

text: Product: About 1,000,000 carbon monoxide alarms distributed by
label: BODY

text: Kidde Safety, including 650,000 Nighthawks and 350,000
label: BODY

text: Lifesavers. The Nighthawk models were made between November
label: BODY

text: 8, 1998 and March 9, 1999. The manufacturing date is on the
label: BODY

text: back of the unit as year, month, day. “NIGHTHAWK” and
label: BODY

text: “Carbon Monoxide Alarm” are on the front of the unit. If
label: BODY

text: “Carbon Monoxide Detector” is on the front, the unit is not part
label: BODY

text: of the recall. The Lifesaver units being recalled are models 9CO-1
label: BODY

text: and 9CO-1C made between June 1, 1997 and January 31, 1998.
label: BODY

text: The manufacturing date is on the back of the unit as the first six
label: BODY

text: numbers in the serial number, located above the UPC code. The
label: BODY

text: date is written as day, month, year. “LIFESAVER” and “Carbon
label: BODY

text: Monoxide Alarm” are on the front of the unit. Hardware and
label: BODY

text: mass merchandise stores nationwide sold the alarms beginning in
label: BODY

text: 1998 for about $20 to $50.
label: BODY

text: Problem: The Lifesaver models could alarm late or not at all, and
label: BODY

text: the Nighthawk models could alarm late. The alarms are used to
label: BODY

text: detect carbon monoxide (CO) leaking from fuel burning appli-
label: BODY

text: ances. When they don’t work, consumers can be unknowingly ex-
label: BODY

text: posed to hazardous levels of CO and suffer injury or death. Kidde
label: BODY

text: Safety and CPSC are not aware of any injuries involving these
label: BODY

text: products.
label: BODY

text: What to do: Visit the Kidde Safety recall web site at
label: BODY

text: www.nhawk.com and follow the instructions or call 1-888-543-
label: BODY

text: 3346 between 8 a.m. and 8 p.m. EST M-S for help identifying re-
label: BODY

text: called units and to get a postage-paid envelope to return the
label: BODY

text: alarm. Lifesaver models will be repaired; Nighthawk models will
label: BODY

text: be tested, and repaired if needed. All returned alarms will be re-
label: BODY

text: certified to UL-2034. Kidde says it will return consumers’ alarms
label: BODY

text: within 30 days.
label: BODY

text: Product: About 424,000 GE Spacemaker radio cassette players dis-
label: BODY

text: tributed by Thomson Consumer Electronics. The model number
label: BODY

text: is 7-4285 and is located on the top of the unit. It may or may not
label: BODY

text: be followed by a letter. The player is designed for under-the-cabi-
label: BODY

text: net use. Each has an AM/FM stereo cassette player, a light, and a
label: BODY

text: programmable appliance outlet with timer. The outlet is on the
label: BODY

text: left side of the unit. “GE Spacemaker...AM/FM Stereo Cassette
label: BODY

text: Player...Programmable Appliance Outlet” is on the front of the
label: BODY

text: unit. Department, electronic and discount stores nationwide sold
label: BODY

text: the radio cassette players from January 1992 through December
label: BODY

text: 1995 for about $50 to $80.
label: BODY

text: Problem: The player has an appliance outlet that can overheat,
label: BODY

text: presenting a fire hazard. Thomson Consumer Electronics has re-
label: BODY

text: ceived three reports of the appliance outlets overheating and
label: BODY

text: catching fire, causing minor property damage. No injuries were
label: BODY

text: reported.
label: BODY

text: What to do: Unplug the units and call Thomson at 1-800-464-7022
label: BODY

text: anytime for instructions and a free replacement unit or contact
label: BODY

text: Thomson at www.home-electronics.net/recall or write Thomson
label: BODY

text: Consumer Electronics, Spacemaker Recall, INH 950, P.O. Box
label: BODY

text: 6127, Indianapolis, IN 46206-6127
label: BODY

text: — Marc Schoem and Terri Rogers, Office of Compliance
label: BODY

text: Consumer Product Safety Review Spring 1999
label: BODY

text: NHTSA Recalls
label: H3

text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is the gov-
label: BODY

text: ernment agency responsible for improving safety on our Nation’s highways.
label: BODY

text: As part of its efforts to achieve this goal, NHTSA is authorized to order
label: BODY

text: manufacturers to recall and repair vehicles or items of motor vehicle equip-
label: BODY

text: ment (including air bags, tires, and child safety seats).
label: BODY

text: The following safety recall campaigns are being conducted in coopera-
label: BODY

text: tion with NHTSA. For more information about NHTSA recall activities,
label: BODY

text: you can access NHTSA on the Internet at http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov or by
label: BODY

text: calling the NHTSA Auto Safety Hotline at 1-888-DASH-2-DOT (1-888-
label: BODY

text: AmTran Corporation
label: BODY

text: AmTran is recalling 8,217 1993-1999 Genesis, FE, 1996-1999 RE,
label: BODY

text: 1997-1999 Conventional, and 1993-1997 Volunteer school buses
label: BODY

text: equipped with flip seats at the emergency exits. The seat cushion
label: BODY

text: hinge on the combination flip seat is located in such a manner that
label: BODY

text: it is within easy reach of the passenger sitting in the seat located be-
label: BODY

text: hind the combo flip seat. The hinges on the combo flip seat can
label: BODY

text: pinch or sever fingers, resulting in personal injury. [NHTSA Recall
label: BODY

text: No. 99V061/ AmTran Recall No. 99-303]
label: BODY

text: Bayerische Motoren Werke
label: BODY

text: BMW is recalling 32,500 1999 BMW 323i and 328i vehicles built
label: BODY

text: with a side air bag system consisting of door-mounted thorax air
label: BODY

text: bags (rear door air bags are optional), a Head Protection System
label: BODY

text: (HPS) for front occupants, a central electronic sensor and diagnos-
label: BODY

text: tic system, left and right satellite impact sensors, and associated
label: BODY

text: wiring, manufactured from June 1998 through March 1999. This
label: BODY

text: system is unduly sensitive to certain non-crash impacts, such as con-
label: BODY

text: tacting large potholes or curbs at substantial speed. This could
label: BODY

text: cause the side air bag and HPS to deploy without an actual side
label: BODY

text: crash. Owners who do not receive the free remedy within a reason-
label: BODY

text: able time should contact BMW at 1-800-831-1117. [NHTSA Recall
label: BODY

text: DaimlerChrysler
label: BODY

text: Chrysler is recalling 263,000 1995-1997 Dodge Ram van and wagon
label: BODY

text: model vehicles manufactured from August 1994 through August
label: BODY

text: 1997. If water/road salt gets on the interior floor of the vehicle in
label: BODY

text: the proximity of the air bag electronic control module (AECM),
label: BODY

text: the AECM can corrode. The resulting corrosion can cause the dri-
label: BODY

text: ver side air bag to deploy inadvertently. Deployment of the air bag
label: BODY

text: without warning could cause a driver to lose vehicle control, in-
label: BODY

text: creasing the risk of a crash and personal injury. Owners who do
label: BODY

text: not receive the free remedy within a reasonable time should con-
label: BODY

text: tact Chrysler at 1-800-992-1997. [NHTSA Recall No.
label: BODY

text: 99V023/Chrysler Recall No. 815]
label: BODY

text: Ford Motor Company
label: BODY

text: Ford is recalling 757,000 1992-1997 Ford Aerostar Mini Vans man-
label: BODY

text: ufactured from August 1991 through August 1997. These vehicles
label: BODY

text: were produced with a higher than specified electrical load through
label: BODY

text: the accessory power feed circuit that connects to the A2 (accesso-
label: BODY

text: ry) terminal within the ignition switch. As a result, during startup,
label: BODY

text: electrical arcing of the A2 terminal to the terminal bridge could
label: BODY

text: potentially cause pitting of the bridge. This condition, over time,
label: BODY

text: could create a short circuit and allow current to flow through the
label: BODY

text: ground wiring, causing overheating and the potential for a vehicle
label: BODY

text: fire. Owners who do not receive the free remedy within a reason-
label: BODY

text: able time should contact Ford at 1-800-392-3673. [NHTSA Recall
label: BODY

text: No. 99V029/Ford Recall No. 99S02]
label: BODY

text: Ford will also recall 895,000 certain 1997-1999 RHD Explorer
label: BODY

text: equipped with 4.0L OHV/SOHC engines and speed control built
label: BODY

text: from May 29, 1996 through March 4, 1999; 1998-1999
label: BODY

text: Explorer/Mountaineers equipped with 4.0L OHV/SOHC or 5.0L
label: BODY

text: engines or 1998-1999 Rangers equipped with 2.5L, 3.0L FFV/EFI
label: BODY

text: or 4.0L engines and speed control built from January 5, 1998
label: BODY

text: through March 4, 1999; 1998-1999 Mustangs equipped with 3.8L,
label: BODY

text: 4.6L 2-valve or 4-valve engines and speed control built from March
label: BODY

text: 8,500 lbs.) trucks equipped with 5.4L or 6.8L engines and speed
label: BODY

text: control built from March 2, 1998 through March 4, 1999; and
label: BODY

text: 1999 F-53 stripped chassis equipped with 5.4L or 6.8L engines and
label: BODY

text: speed control built from March 2, 1998 through March 4, 1999.
label: BODY

text: The speed control cable can interfere with the speed control servo
label: BODY

text: pulley and not allow the throttle to return to idle when disengag-
label: BODY

text: ing the speed control. If the speed control is used and this condi-
label: BODY

text: tion is present, a stuck throttle could result, increasing the
label: BODY

text: potential for a crash.  Owners who do not receive the free remedy
label: BODY

text: within a reasonable time should contact Ford at 1-800-392-3673.
label: BODY

text: [NHTSA Recall No. 99V062/Ford Recall No. 99S09]
label: BODY

text: Harley-Davidson Motor Company
label: BODY

text: Harley-Davidson is recalling 14,211 1999 FLHT, FLHTC, FL-
label: BODY

text: HTCUI,  FLHTCI, FLHTPI, FLTR, FLTRI, FLHR, FLHPI,
label: BODY

text: FLHP, FLHRCI, FXDL, FXDWG, FXDS CONV, FXD, and FXDX
label: BODY

text: motorcycles manufactured from February 1998 through January
label: BODY

text: 1999. The engine cam bolt can lose its clamp load and/or break.
label: BODY

text: This condition can cause the engine to quit running with or without
label: BODY

text: prior warning. In some instances, the engine could run erratically
label: BODY

text: before quitting. Owners who do not receive the free remedy within a
label: BODY

text: reasonable time should contact Harley-Davidson at 1-414-342-4680.
label: BODY

text: [NHTSA Recall No. 99V003/Harley-Davidson Recall No. 095]
label: BODY

text: General Motors Corporation
label: BODY

text: GM is recalling 2,090 1996-1998 Chevrolet Astro and GMC Safari
label: BODY

text: minivans equipped with integrated child seats and manufactured
label: BODY

text: from May 1996 through September 1997. Some of these vehicles
label: BODY

text: may be missing a seat belt retractor clutch spring and/or pawl
label: BODY

text: spring in the child seat. If the clutch spring was missing, the seat
label: BODY

text: belt would lock in the retracted position and could not be used. If
label: BODY

text: the pawl spring was missing, the seat belt restraint would continu-
label: BODY

text: ally play out and not lock. These conditions could increase the oc-
label: BODY

text: cupant’s risk of injury in the event of a vehicle crash. Dealers will
label: BODY

text: inspect the seat belts on the child seats, and if necessary, replace
label: BODY

text: the child seat. Owners who do not receive the free remedy within
label: BODY

text: a reasonable time should contact Chevrolet at 1-800-222-1020 or
label: BODY

text: GMC at 1-800-462-8782. [NHTSA Recall No. 99V009/GM Recall
label: BODY

text: GM is also recalling 988,587 1994 Chevrolet C10, C20, C30,
label: BODY

text: C3500, Suburban, GMC C15, C25, C35, C3500, and Suburban ve-
label: BODY

text: hicles manufactured from March 1993 through September 1994.
label: BODY

text: These vehicles were built with the polarity of the wiring for the
label: BODY

text: brake switch reversed from what was specified on the switch draw-
label: BODY

text: ing. With the reversed polarity, the contacts in the brake switch
label: BODY

text: can wear out prematurely. The brake switch will perform normal-
label: BODY

text: ly until the brake switch contacts wear out, resulting in loss of the
label: BODY

text: brake lamps without any warning to the driver. This would fail to
label: BODY

text: warn a following driver that the vehicle is braking and could lead
label: BODY

text: to a crash. Owners who do not receive the free remedy within a
label: BODY

text: reasonable time should contact Chevrolet at 1-800-222-1020 or
label: BODY

text: GMC at 1-800-462-8782. [NHTSA Recall No. 99V025/GM Recall
label: BODY
